WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: You don't need any certification up until you start working with H motors. Within that range, the most you'll ever spend on a rocket is probably $350, and most of that money would be spent on the motor case and avionics systems, which are reusable and can easily be moved between different rockets.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: In OpenRocket, there is a rocket optimization feature that can do that.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mars_Climate_Orbiter

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Good to know. I already made some modifications, so the rocket should be stable as long as it has fins.  I haven't been able to get a result from FinSim, so I'm probably doing something wrong. I might just model the fins based on Additive Aerospace's design, since they've been proven to work up to Mach 2.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: [This is the fiberglass I ordered](https://www.buyrocketmotors.com/38mm-filament-wound-fiberglass-airframes-standard/)  The engine block will most likely be necessary due to the amount of force being exerted on the airframe. It should help distribute it a little more evenly.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: The fins are polycarbonate, not fiberglass.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: How conservative should I be with the fin dimensions to avoid flutter? I've tried using FinSim, but I can't get a result.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I haven't even started building the rocket yet. I made a fin can, but I don't plan on using it for anything more than test flights (testing the computer, not the rocket itself)

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I checked in both OpenRocket and RASAero, and the stability should increase with speed, due to both base drag and the changes in the CG.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'll print a polycarbonate fin can, and the airframe may become longer depending on the amount of space required for the parachute and computer.  Edit: The airframe became longer. The new plan is to do both my L1 and L2 on the same rocket, then fly it on an I1299 to celebrate.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: > First, your stability is questionable, especially since rockets get less stable past mach 1.  Doesn't base drag increase stability?

WRITING.TITLE: b"Will my rocket be able to handle >200G acceleration if it's made of fiberglass?"
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm designing an L1/L2 rocket, and I plan on doing a launch with an I1299. The structure will be made of two standard thickness 38mm body tubes, one \\~350mm long, and one 310mm long. I've asked multiple people with more experience than me, but I've had conflicting answers.  â€‹  [Overview of the OpenRocket design][URL]  Edit:   [Updated design w\\/ better stability and longer airframe capable of fitting a J425 for an L2 flight][URL]

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: How much acceleration can a Pi Zero handle? I'm designing a rocket that will use one as a flight computer, and it'll probably exceed 200G acceleration.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: [FinSim](http://www.aerorocket.com/finsim.html) is more accurate, but it unfortunately doesn't allow for metric units either

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: How?

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'm trying to get it to go to at least 300. My current firmware allows for 260, but I'm getting some problems with underextrusion and weak parts because I can't set the hotend to the correct temperature.

WRITING.TITLE: b'Is there any Ender 3 V2 firmware with a higher temperature limit?'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I got an all-metal hotend so I can print polycarbonate, but I can't find any working firmware with the temperature range I need, and I unsuccessfully tried to compile it myself

WRITING.TITLE: b'Would it be better to just use a small parachute (or just find a way to ditch it entirely)?'
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I attempted my first dual deployment flight (drogueless) and the parachute didn't deploy, but the descent rate was only 11 m/s - definitely higher than ideal, but lower than I expected. Some parts of the structure were damaged, but I think it may have been avoidable with stronger materials (PC/ABS instead of PLA and thin PETG fins) or a tiny parachute to slow it down a bit more. There would be some benefits to reducing the size of the parachute, so is it worth a shot?  The rocket's structure is 100% 3D printed, its dry mass was approximately 285g, and the cross-sectional area was approximately 0.02986m^2. This means the drag coefficient was around 1.63.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: How would I do it, though? I've never worked on a kit rocket before, and the bulkhead is too deep in there for me to access it.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It threw me off, too. I ended up researching the actual sounding rocket instead of the scale model.

WRITING.TITLE: b'I found this really old rocket, but I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find much information on it. Can anyone here identify it?'
b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: Not enough thrust. A Space Shuttle SRB would have 12MN maximum thrust ASL, but 9 Merlin engines combined would only have 7.6MN of thrust. Whether or not Starship works out, this definitely won't.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: It looks like the rocket was in the air for more than 5 seconds after burnout, but the 5 second mark was a little bit later than apogee, and I didn't see any sign of the ejection charge going off. I don't know what would cause that.

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I've launched a rocket with similar mass on the same motor, and it was a perfect flight every time, at least until I tried adding a booster and it hit the ground at well over 100mph.  What caused the chute to not deploy?

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: What motor?

WRITING.TITLE: b' '
WRITING.TEXT.Element:Text: I'll be doing a lot of launches with the same rocket and a variety of different parts pretty soon, so I can let you know how it goes.
